%R 2017ApJ...834..160N
%T Period-Color and Amplitude-Color Relations at Maximum and Minimum Light for RR Lyrae Stars in the SDSS Stripe 82 Region
%A Ngeow, Chow-Choong; Kanbur, Shashi M.; Bhardwaj, Anupam;
Schrecengost, Zachariah; Singh, Harinder P.
%F AA(Graduate Institute of Astronomy, National Central University,
Jhongli 32001, Taiwan), AB(Department of Physics, SUNY Oswego, Oswego,
NY 13126, USA), AC(Department of Physics and Astrophysics, University of
Delhi, Delhi 110007, India; European Southern Observatory, Karl-
Schwarzschild-Straße 2, Garching D-85748, Germany), AD(Department of
Physics, SUNY Oswego, Oswego, NY 13126, USA), AE(Department of Physics
and Astrophysics, University of Delhi, Delhi 110007, India)
%J The Astrophysical Journal
%V 834
%D 01/2017
%P 160
%K stars: atmospheres, stars: fundamental parameters, stars: variables:
RR Lyrae, Astrophysics - Solar and Stellar Astrophysics
%I ABSTRACT: Abstract;
%I Co-Reads: Co-Reads;
%I EPRINT_HTML: arXiv Article;
%I PUB_HTML: Publisher Article;
%I EPRINT_PDF: arXiv PDF;
%I PUB_PDF: Publisher PDF;
%I SIMBAD: SIMBAD Database at the CDS;
%I CDS: Strasbourg Astronomical Data Center;
%U https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2017ApJ...834..160N
%B Investigation of period-color (PC) and amplitude-color (AC) relations at
the maximum and minimum light can be used to probe the interaction of
the hydrogen ionization front (HIF) with the photosphere and the
radiation hydrodynamics of the outer envelopes of Cepheids and RR
Lyraes. For example, theoretical calculations indicated that such
interactions would occur at minimum light for RR Lyrae and result in a
flatter PC relation. In the past, the PC and AC relations have been
investigated by using either the (V - R)<SUB>MACHO</SUB> or (V - I)
colors. In this work, we extend previous work to other bands by
analyzing the RR Lyraes in the Sloan Digital Sky Survey Stripe 82
Region. Multi-epoch data are available for RR Lyraes located within the
footprint of the Stripe 82 Region in five (ugriz) bands. We present the
PC and AC relations at maximum and minimum light in four colors: (u -
g)<SUB>0</SUB>, (g - r)<SUB>0</SUB>, (r - i)<SUB>0</SUB>, and (i -
z)<SUB>0</SUB>, after they are corrected for extinction. We found that
the PC and AC relations for this sample of RR Lyraes show a complex
nature in the form of flat, linear or quadratic relations. Furthermore,
the PC relations at minimum light for fundamental mode RR Lyrae stars
are separated according to the Oosterhoff type, especially in the (g -
r)<SUB>0</SUB> and (r - i)<SUB>0</SUB> colors. If only considering the
results from linear regressions, our results are quantitatively
consistent with the theory of HIF-photosphere interaction for both
fundamental and first overtone RR Lyraes.
%Y DOI: 10.3847/1538-4357/834/2/160
%Y eprintid: arXiv:1612.04486


%R 2017ApJ...834...92C
%T LAMOST Observations of Flaring M Dwarfs in the Kepler Field
%A Chang, H. -Y.; Song, Y. -H.; Luo, A. -L.; Huang, L. -C.; Ip, W. -H.;
Fu, J. -N.; Zhang, Y.; Hou, Y. -H.; Cao, Z. -H.; Wang, Y. -F.
%F AA(Institute of Astronomy, National Central University, 300 Jhongda
Road, Jhongli 32001, Taiwan), AB(Key Laboratory of Optical Astronomy,
National Astronomical Observatories, Chinese Academy of Sciences,
Beijing 100012, China), AC(Key Laboratory of Optical Astronomy, National
Astronomical Observatories, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100012,

Jhongda Road, Jhongli 32001, Taiwan), AE(Institute of Astronomy,
National Central University, 300 Jhongda Road, Jhongli 32001, Taiwan;
Space Science Institute, Macau University of Science and Technology,
Avenida Wailong, Taipa, Macau), AF(Department of Astronomy, Beijing
Normal University, 19 Avenue Xinjiekouwai, Beijing 100875, China),
AG(Nanjing Institute of Astronomical Optics &amp; Technology, National
Astronomical Observatories, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Nanjing 210042,
China), AH(Nanjing Institute of Astronomical Optics &amp; Technology,
National Astronomical Observatories, Chinese Academy of Sciences,
Nanjing 210042, China), AI(Key Laboratory of Optical Astronomy, National
Astronomical Observatories, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100012,
China), AJ(Nanjing Institute of Astronomical Optics &amp; Technology,
National Astronomical Observatories, Chinese Academy of Sciences,
Nanjing 210042, China)
%J The Astrophysical Journal
%V 834
%D 01/2017
%P 92
%K stars: activity, stars: chromospheres, stars: flare, Astrophysics -
Solar and Stellar Astrophysics
%I ABSTRACT: Abstract;
%I Co-Reads: Co-Reads;
%I EPRINT_HTML: arXiv Article;
%I PUB_HTML: Publisher Article;
%I EPRINT_PDF: arXiv PDF;
%I PUB_PDF: Publisher PDF;
%I SIMBAD: SIMBAD Database at the CDS;
%I MAST: Mikulski Archive for Space Telescopes;
%U https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2017ApJ...834...92C
%B A sample of the Large Sky Area Multi-Object Fibre Spectroscopic
Telescope spectra of early-type M0-M3 dwarfs is compared with Kepler
observations. It is found that M dwarfs with strong chromospheric
emission in {{{H}}}<SUB>α </SUB> have large flare activity in general.
The rotational periods derived from the Kepler measurements have close
correlations with the sizes of the flares, the power-law distribution
index, and the equivalent widths of the {{{H}}}<SUB>α </SUB> emission. A
clear trend exists for higher magnetic activities being detected in
faster-rotating M dwarfs (rotation periods &lt; 20 days).
%Y DOI: 10.3847/1538-4357/834/1/92
%Y eprintid: arXiv:1610.04541
